Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Analysis in Lyon; October 26-30, 2015; Lyon, France
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the workshop "Analysis in Lyon" which occur at the École Normale Supérieure de Lyon, October 26-30, 2015.

This workshop focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of partial differential equations. The topics to be covered in the workshop are gradient flows, regularity theory for optimal transport, Ricci curvature flows, pressureless gas dynamics, fractional diffusion, and kinetic theory. This award gives young researchers without other funding the opportunity to participate in this workshop. A (partial) list of confirmed speakers includes L. Caffarelli, W. Gangbo, S. Serfaty, F. Lin and C. Villani. The organizing committee will strive to make this opportunity known to target groups through a variety of media.

The workshop website is at: http://perso.ens-lyon.fr/marco.mazzucchelli/analysis-lyon2015/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop has been organized as part of a thematic semester in Lyon (France) about the topic of analysis and partial differential equations.

At the workshop, 23 world-wide recognized speakers from all over the world gave a one-hour presentation on their most recent research.

Also, as part of the workshop, one of the speaker (Luigi Ambrosio from the Scuola Normale Superiore of Pisa, Italy) was awarded a Phd Honoris Causa from the Ecole Normale Superieure of Lyon.

The focus of this workshop has been on contemporary trends in analysis, with particular emphasys on PDE and numerical analysis, mathematical problems of fluid mechanics and plasma physics, optimal transport theory, calculus of variations, functional analysis, fluid mechanics, and mathematical aspects of materials sciences. The proposed meeting has been a unique combination of mainstream topics in analysis with highly interdisciplinary contemporary directions situated at the overlap of major research areas.

As a result of this workshop, young researchers had the opportunity to learn from top mathematicians. There has been a balance between classical results (that need to be understood in order to appreciate further research) and more contemporary ones. The highly interdisciplinary nature of the research presented at the conference also provided ample opportunities for researchers of all ages to communicate with experts in various fields and form new collaborations. 

Participation of mathematicians with diverse backgrounds has been encouraged, while some of the application-oriented talks had been of great interest to engineers as well as physical scientists. The organizers made a consistent effort to ensure that the topics discussed covered a full spectrum between purely theoretical and highly applied topics.

The speakers from the USA were only two (Luis Caffarelli, Fanghua Lin); apart from supporting the visit of few more faculty from US (such as Adrian Tudorascu), most of the support requested from this grant has used for graduate students and postdocs. Notice that both speakers from the USA (Luis Caffarelli and Wilfrid Gangbo) qualify as underrepresented groups.

This workshop has been a real success, with more than 100 participants coming from all over the world.
